In Nursing 531, forensic mental health is the interface between the law and mental health. This course examines the components of human behavior that bring people into a judicial setting. The content covers criminal personalities, forensic interview and the role of forensic psychiatry. Domestic violence offenders, sex offenders, stalkers, gang members, and offenders who commit homicide will also be discussed. Definitions and dynamics of criminal motherhood and the psychodynamics of violent juvenile offenders will be presented. Use of the Internet by offenders will also be discussed. This course also offers a field experience in which students will interview incarcerated individuals.

Feedback for the course was almost unanimously positive. Students complimented the interesting lectures and subject matter, as well as the thought-provoking writing assignments. Concerning the writing assignments, one student stated that “they made [her] a better writer because they were assigned frequently and about interesting topics.” However, one student wrote that the group project was frustrating in that there was not always an equal division of labor among group members. 

Most students complimented Professor Brown’s lecturing capabilities. However, one student wrote that the professors acknowledged that problems concerning group work ethic existed, but did not act to rectify the situation.

Students generally felt that the course was extremely interesting and not very difficult. Some students wrote that the writing assignments did require a good amount of time, but the topics were interesting enough that it was not a problem.

This course focuses on the intersection of mental health and criminal law and examines the components of human behavior that bring people into a judicial setting. The content covered in this course includes: criminal personalities, forensic interview, and the role of forensic psychiatry. The class also delves deep into the psychology behind various criminal offenses such as stalking and sexual offenses.

Overall, students seemed to enjoy this course. Many said that it was “excellent,” “great,” and had “interesting subject material.” Most of the students reflected favorably on assigned readings and viewed the writing requirements as enjoyable.

The majority of the students found Professors Weisser and Dollard to be very engaging both inside and outside of the classroom. Students also enjoyed the “excellent” and “well selected” guest lectures that were an integral part of the class.

This course was recommended for upperclassmen only. Most students found that grading in this course was fair. Many students praised the Wiki-Project that was assigned to them as “helpful,” as they said that it allowed them to “gain a better understanding” of the material presented in class. However, a few students complained that the group project did not adequately reflect their effort in the course due to poor member effort and involvement.

Domestic violence offenders, sex offenders, stalkers, gang members, and offenders who commit homicide will also be discussed. Definitions and dynamics of criminal motherhood and the psychodynamics of violent juvenile offenders will be presented. Use of the Internet by offenders will also be discussed. This course also offers a field experience in which students will interview incarcerated individuals.

One student described the class as “awesome,” while one thought that not enough students did the readings because there were not further assignments or tests over them. 

Students did not leave explicit feedback about Professor Garblik.

One student felt that the readings were not absolutely necessary for tests and assignments and thought that it was nice to not have assignments due weekly in recitation.

This review is based off of the 2 responses that were submitted.
